title: What will be the value of the S&P/Case-Shiller US National Home Price Index for October 2021?
preds: Living on the wild side for a day. It has to be bin 4 because of the momentum of the index.
I'll hold at 50/50 to balance against the crowd, but I think it's probably more like 60% bin 3, 40% bin 4.
And another, moving closer to crowd consensus

Adjusting my bets up a bit after running a set of monte-carlo linear extrapolations.  Adding a little to Bin5 as a hedge, but if the index really went there my Brier Scores will take a huge hit anyway - bad enough after some poor calls last year.  Main chips are in bin4 now.  Will be interesting to see where this ends up.

Existing house sales have increased 7% in September alone while also seeing nearly a 3 point increase in the National Home Price Index from July to August. This increase has remained steady, suggesting we will see another increase pushing the index over the 268.86 mark its at right now. More information on the current housing situation here: https://www.noradarealestate.com/blog/housing-market-predictions/
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CSUSHPINSA Update on 26th Octobre zo 268, rising 3 basis point from July. Estimating samf increase for September and Octobre well are well in the 270+ level

Very close to the 270 threshold, but leaving plenty of probability on sub 270 as others have pointed out that home prices have started to decline and the 3 month average in the shiller index could start to follow that pattern. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/HOSMEDUSM052N

@belikewater and others have raised good points about why the index may diverge from the median home price so updating in that direction. Meanwhile, I think there are good reasons to think this could resolve in bin 3 as per my previous comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1348092
To me, when I factor in the crowd, it's a toss-up. Good luck everyone!

I'm going a bit out on a limb here, but I've convinced myself that because the ascent in the index has been so steep, the index is going to take a little while to adjust to the declining median sales price of existing homes, i.e., to plateau and start declining itself. Looking back at the index, it really does appear that the faster (steeper) the change, the more the index tends to be decoupled from and to lag the MSP and to take a little time to come back in sync with it. This is a tricky, unprecedented situation that does not easily lend itself to various modeling methods.
Thanks to @JonathanMann, @BayesianChimp, and @erikbays for very useful discussions.

Updating based on the FRED August numbers.  I was projecting August to be lower than the 268.62 value.  So kudos to @belikewater who came in much closer than me on this per our discussion the other day.  Rerunning my 4cast using Winter's Method I obtain results that imply an increased probability for Bin4, so I'm changing my forecast.  I went back to the FRED MSP data and found a longer time series dataset for regression, but have abandoned this because of the strong seasonal component in the MSP that increases the error variance in the regression against CSHPI.  If I run 3 month moving averages of the MSP I definitely see a slow down there as noted by @JonathanMann.  So taking that into account I end up with a slight bias towards Bin4 over Bin3.

Based on the slightly higher than projected August numbers, my model is now projecting September as ~266 and October as ~264.
Here are my calculations: 
The three-month average for August was 360000 which when multiplied by my prediction parameter ("0.000742") would have yielded "267.12". Adjusting this parameter to "0.000745" would have yielded "268.2", still slightly low, but that's as far as I'm willing to move it based on a single observation. 
With these adjustments in place, the three-month average for September (356,667) multiplied by the "0.000745" parameter yields "265.72".
We don't have the median sales price data for October yet, but given the seasonal trends and looking at the past few months, I think it's reasonable to predict that it will be lower than September. With that said, I'll use the September number for October for now.
Based on the stated assumptions, the three-month average for October becomes 354,433. When it is multiplied by the "0.000745" parameter, it yields "264.05".
Of course, there is a pretty wide range of variation around these estimates, but it appears that we're still most likely to end up in bin 3. 
Given the fact that @belikewater 's estimates for August were closer than mine though, I'm going to have to update slightly toward his forecast.
@LokiOdinevich , @elifland - Any thoughts?
Data used to compute three-month rolling averages: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/HOSMEDUSM052N

The August value is out: 268.616. I had forecast an approximate value of 268.4. 1.384 more to go to end up in bin 4. I think bin 4 is most likely; I think it'll end up just over 271. I think there's some possibility the index could also increase a bit more but not quite reach 270, but I don't think the October value is likely to go below 268. I'm shifting my forecast a little extra strongly towards bin 4 than I probably should, just for fun. (It should probably actually be 30%/70%.) I think this is my final forecast. @BayesianChimp @JonathanMann: While the MSP of existing homes peaked in June and has declined gently thereafter, I suspect that the S&P/Case-Shiller index will not peak in August because I suspect the upward trend in the S&P/Case-Shiller index hasn't fully ended yet. There is some additional information in the S&P/Case-Shiller index that is not captured in the MSP of existing homes, relating to the previous sale price of a home whose sale is used to calculate the S&P/Case-Shiller index. The S&P/Case-Shiller index always looks at prices in pairs, whereas the MSP is calculated based only on recent sales, with no regard to the previous sale price of any home. I believe it is likely for this reason that the S&P/Case-Shiller index has continued to trend upwards since Dec 2012 while never dropping so much as 0.5 in value from month to month (and in some years strictly increasing each month), while the MSP of existing homes has dropped considerably more percentage-wise at times since then. Thus, I would be wary of predicting that the S&P/Case-Shiller index will fall based on the fact that a 3-month moving average of the MSP of existing homes peaked in August. The S&P/Case-Shiller index may turn out to have peaked in August if the upward trend in the S&P/Case-Shiller index is actually over, but I suspect it isn't.

maintaining current forecast, but wanted to get this out before the new numbers are released.
plus or minus 5 for August and getting even more uncertain as things get further out, I'm targeting:
August: ~267,	September: ~265,	October: ~263
I'll adjust my forecast depending on the August number that gets released.
It seems housing prices peaked in June, so I'm expecting the rolling three-month average will peak in August and then go down from there.
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/HOSMEDUSM052N

Good comments and discussion by fellow forecasters @JonathanMann @belikewater @LokiOdinevich.  Using the MSP data available regressed against the Case-Shiller Index and the https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/case-shiller-home-price-index#:~:text=In%20the%20long%2Dterm%2C%20the,according%20to%20our%20econometric%20models forecast, I aggregated with my RWalk and Winter's Method 4cast.  After all this fine work I'm now oscillating between Bin3 and Bin4.  Feels like I'm sitting on the fence while Rome is burning...

Updating again based on @belikewater 's comments: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1347215
Also, as @belikewater noted, I had not taken into account that this is a three-month moving average as per the "Approaches" sub-section of the "Index Construction" section of this document: https://www.spglobal.com/spdji/en/documents/methodologies/methodology-sp-corelogic-cs-home-price-indices.pdf
I'll try to rerun my analysis again when I get time, but making a knee-jerk update.

@LokiOdinevich , @belikewater ,  @elifland , @cafebedouin -  After additional consideration, a ~10% risk for 250 - 260 is warranted. 
I had previously been using the noisy metro area data set with weightings to make my estimates, but, switched to this cleaner national data set (also from realtor.com): 
https://econdata.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/Reports/Core/RDC_Inventory_Core_Metrics_Country_History.csv
It shows that the median list price fell from 385,000 in July to 380,000 in August and remained flat in September (also 380,000). 
List prices in this data set do not map exactly to FRED, but this method would put the target FRED number for August / September closer ~262 (about this same level as June), but with a fair amount of wiggle room. Add on to that the fact that October could take another step down and the 250 - 260 bucket looks very possible. With all that said, I still think the arguments @cafebedouin made are probably right, but I'm going to give the 250 - 260 bin some extra weight : https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1347126
I do think bin 4 is more likely, but I hesitate to be so strongly against the crowd and good researchers who have likely investigated this forecast more than I have.

Aligning myself with @JonathanMann's forecast. Ultimately, I put a bunch of effort at the beginning of the question (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1314565), but haven't been following it closely since then. Also, I do think that if the market had crashed in October, we'd have heard about it by now.

The forecasts presented here are aligned with my own projections (based on seasonal trends and market data sampling):
https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/case-shiller-home-price-index#:~:text=In%20the%20long%2Dterm%2C%20the,according%20to%20our%20econometric%20models.
(click the "forecasts" tab to view the forecasts for coming months)
Note that the monthly numbers in the link are consistently skewed a few clicks higher than the FRED data, so take that into account. 
The data for my independent analysis came from here: https://www.realtor.com/research/data/
From what I can tell, the upward trend seems to have been arrested in August and is now closer to following the normal seasonal trend (but at elevated prices).
I think @cafebedouin 's estimate is about right, but hedging toward the crowd a bit: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1339600
I may adjust dramatically if the FRED August number is not in line with my projections (i.e. 264 - 269).
Will this forecast be the start of another information cascade?

The median sales price of existing homes continued to decline gently, albeit slightly faster than the previous couple months:
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/HOSMEDUSM052N
I still think it's likely that the Aug value will add approximately 3 to the index, for a value of ~268.4, and I suspect that the combined effects of Sept and Oct will be >+1.6, although I think there is some risk of bin 3, especially as the MSP is declining slightly more steeply. As before, if Aug comes in at >=268.2, I'll probably increase my forecast towards bin 4.
Shifting some.  This one is difficult with having such a long lag in data.  Hope I'm not reacting to noise.

I do think it likely that the Aug value will add approximately 3 to the index, for a value of ~268.4. And I suspect that the combined effects of Sept and Oct will be >+1.6. If Aug comes in at >=268.2, I'll probably increase my forecast towards bin 4.

The median listing price for Sept 21 was the same as in August, which suggests to me that the median sales prices for Sept might be a bit lower than in August (perhaps $353.5k to $354.0k), continuing its gentle fall with an approximately constant slope. If this were a more typical year (like 2012 through 2019), I'd say the index would be likely to go up by 1 or at most 2 by Oct. But based more on last year, I think it'll go up ~3 in Aug, then ~2 in Sept, maybe ~1 in Oct. This forecast is right on the line between bins and is going to be a nailbiter.
https://www.realtor.com/research/september-2021-data/ Later edit: I just realized this forecast closes on Nov. 1. So we're only going to know index values up through August by then.

Minor adjustment.  Two possible themes here: One being that CSHPI will moderate and end up in Bin 3 (260 to 270), most likely due to seasonal effects that occur around this time.  Another thought is that it will continue to rise more slowly due to some moderation in the underlying home prices (eg, median sales price), but will still end up in bin 4 (270 to 280) by the end of the competition due to the moving average nature of the index.  At present, I'm not sure and am hedging with slightly more chips in Bin 3 than 4.

Updating based the 9/28 index results using Winter's Method forecast averaged with a Random Walk Model forecast.  Looking like bins 3 and 4 most likely, which is similar to comment from @belikewater.   At the moment have a few more chips on 260 to 270 vs 270 to 280, but will change as needed.

Index at 265.350 on Sept 28. Last month, I forecasted growth of ~4 for July for the forecast index; actual July growth was 4.24.
Only 3 months in the forecast. The forecast is becoming constrained.
The median sales price (MSP) of existing homes peaked in June and declined gently in July and August. I expect it to continue to decline gently in Sept and Oct. As a consequence, I'll expect the forecast index, which is a 3-month moving average of data related to the MSP of existing homes, to increase by ~3 for Aug, ~2 for Sept and maybe ~1 for Oct.
https://ycharts.com/indicators/us_existing_home_median_sales_price
Suppose growth in the index for each month:
Aug 4, Sept 4, Oct 3 => 276.35 (a very unlikely maximum scenario)
Aug 4, Sept 3, Oct 3 => 275.35
Aug 3, Sept 2, Oct 2 => 272.35 
Aug 3, Sept 2, Oct 1 => 271.35 (an approx scenario I think most likely)
Aug 3, Sept 2, Oct 0 => 270.35
Aug 3, Sept 0, Oct 0 => 268.35
Aug 2, Sept 0, Oct -1 => 266.35
Aug 1, Sept -2, Oct -2 => 262.35 (an extremely unlikely minimum scenario)
Only bins 3 and 4 are realistic. I think the index is likely to be approx 271 to 272, or with a wider margin, 270.35 to 274.35. Unfortunately, that is close to the boundary between bins.

Updating estimates for the most recent print. I'm assuming that the trend away from cities will continue for the next 3 months, that the housing market will remain attractive for the wealthy (who I believe are the only people left in the market for homes now), and that residential real estate will remain attractive to investors as we head into choppy financial waters (i.e. worldwide power outages, China property boom over, etc).
Even though the MSP of existing homes is gently declining, I think the index will likely to continue to gently rise throughout the remainder of the forecast period.
Minor adjustment based on Zillow, National Assoc of Realtors info.  Leaving a little bit in the tails.
Adjusting after subset aggregation and evaluation of Zillow & Fannie May analyses.

Based on redfin data it appears that prices peaked in July. While the Case-Shiller will likely be higher in July than June, I think it could be even to decreasing after that.

https://www.redfin.com/news/housing-market-update-pending-sales-up-9pct/
Updating forecast for linear trend and new stdev numbers.
Updated based on June number with aggregation subset of crowd.

Up to date data suggests that the median sales price of existing homes may have already peaked in June. Reducing bin 5 and adjusting forecast downward a bit. Now forecasting growth of ~4 for July for the forecast index.
https://ycharts.com/indicators/us_existing_home_median_sales_price
Suppose growth in the index for each month:
July 5.5, Aug 5, Sept 4, Oct 3 => 278
July 5, Aug 4, Sept 3, Oct 3 => 276
July 5, Aug 3, Sept 2, Oct 2 => 273
July 4, Aug 3, Sept 2, Oct 2 => 271.8
July 4, Aug 3, Sept 2, Oct 0 => 269.8
July 4, Aug 1, Sept -2, Oct -2 => 261.8 (a minimum scenario)
If the decline in the median sale price for existing homes continues for August, then I think that will rule out bin 5.

Reevaluating as it's continued to climb. I expected it to begin to level off already so I was wrong there. I still believe there's a chance it drops as housing supply has continued to rise which may result in pushing the housing costs back down, but maybe it won't. Housing supply: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/MSACSR

June value: 260.866. Increase of 5.568 over May. Still a really big increase.
The Index has a seasonal trend of enhanced increases from March through July that start to taper off in August and declines after that, until the following March. This trend is superimposed on overall growth of the index and can be seen even in 2020 and 2021, except that growth didn't decline at the end of the summer in 2020. Will we see a decline in growth through the end of summer in 2021? One factor in favor of a decline in growth is that the economy is gradually returning to pre-pandemic activities; one factor against this is that new housing construction has faced shortages, and these bottlenecks may push more people into purchasing existing housing stock who would otherwise have purchased new homes. (No new homes are included in this Index.)
This feels like a bubble that will gradually pop as people have to go back to the office and won't want to commute to their suburban dream houses. But I don't think the bubble is likely to pop before October, especially as a lot of people continue to telecommute and high levels of Covid spread continue. And also, there is generally a housing crisis in the US, so in the end, maybe it will simply be a gradual slide rather than pop.
Also, the median home sale price is starting to plateau (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/MSPUS), which can be a leading indicator for the forecast Index (see, e.g., 2005). A risk to consider is that we'll see a decline in the median home sale price for Q3 like that seen in Q3 of 2006; this corresponded to a fall of about half a point in the forecast index. However, as the median home sale price grew ~5% for July, I don't think a substantial decline in the median home sale price for Q3 or any decline in the forecast index is likely in the forecast period. But it is clear that the housing market is approaching some kind of peak.
So I'll expect another month of growth of ~5 pts/month for July, followed by a bit less growth in August and a little less in September and October, but I'll allow for the possibility that growth will continue at existing levels for July through October. Looking at 2020, I don't think avg growth >5 pts/month is out of the question, but I don't think 2021 will be like 2020 because the median home sale price was exploding in Q3 2020 but is starting to plateau now.
Possible outcomes are constrained by time at this point. Only 4 months of data remaining in the forecast.
Average growth rate for remaining 4 months, index value:
1, 264.87
2, 268.87
3, 272.87
4, 276.87
5, 280.87
5.6, 283.14
6, 284.87 Suppose: 
July 5.5, Aug 5, Sept 4, Oct 3 => 278
July 5, Aug 4, Sept 3, Oct 3 => 276
July 5, Aug 3, Sept 2, Oct 2 => 273
I think the most likely outcome is bin 4. If the July growth is close to 5, then that would constrain my forecast closer to bin 4.

Buyer confidence is falling and sales are falling because prices are getting beyond what people can afford, but home values are still increasing. I'm seeing 12-20% annual price increases in the territory that I appraise in, although Oregon is seeing prices rise more rapidly than the rest of the United States.
https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/us-home-prices-rise-fastest-pace-record

Buyer confidence is falling and sales are falling because prices are getting beyond what people can afford, but home values are still increasing. Updating forecast for the 5 point increase published on July 27th. Continuation of trend from February 2021 to October 2021 = 282, although homebuyer sentiment fell sharply in August (which isn't visible in the Case Schiller data yet).
Why-oh-why did I forecast on this question. No update.

Updating slightly after reading some of the commentary and analysis by @LokiOdinevich.  Then aggregated with peers using Satopaa's method.

Adjusting some after discussion with @LokiOdinevich and @JonathanMann:
1. I'm more convinced that there are some reasons to expect growth in the index to slow down from the last year/ few months. COVID may have contributed a lot to the consistent large increase and as COVID restrictions wind down , inflation decreases and the eviction moratorium ends, the index might not increase by as much.
2. But, if inflation is causing some of the recent rapid increases, inflation was high (0.9%) in June: https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/cpi.pdf.

- Eviction moratorium => Opens up inventory
- Inflation, new housing
- Interest rates Making my prediction slightly more spread out.

Among other issues, I'm not sure what the effects of lifting the eviction moratorium are going to be. It probably won't be too large, though, because many people have been able to restructure their mortgages.
How high can this go? It feels like a bubble that will pop when people have to go back to the office, and suddenly no one will want to commute to their suburban dream houses. But I don't think the bubble is likely to pop before October.
Growth rate for remaining 5 months, index value:
1, 259.92
2, 264.92
3, 269.92
4, 274.92
5, 279.92
I can't picture growth staying as high as 5 pts/month for the remainder of the forecast period, but 280+ shouldn't be ruled out at this point.
Also, the median home sale price is plateauing (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/MSPUS), which can be a leading indicator (see, e.g., 2005).
Still, it seems like any peak or plateau is likely still a few months away. If this is true, then bins 1 and 2 would be unlikely.
Extrapolation; pace from last few months would end at about 280, pace from before that would end at about 270. Most likely to end up somewhere in between.
Giving slightly more weight to Fannie Mae data.

Part 1: Background reading notes. Background: The index really jumped in April.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/29/home-price-gains-in-april-truly-extraordinary-sp-case-shiller-says.html
> “April’s performance was truly extraordinary. The 14.6% gain in the National Composite is literally the highest reading in more than 30 years of S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller data,” said Craig Lazzara, managing director and global head of index investment strategy at S&P Dow Jones Indices. > Not only did home prices rise in all 20 cities, but the price gains accelerated in all as well and were in the top quartile of performance historically. > “We have previously suggested that the strength in the U.S. housing market is being driven in part by reaction to the COVID pandemic, as potential buyers move from urban apartments to suburban homes. April’s data continue to be consistent with this hypothesis,” added Lazzara.

> Home sales have been falling for the past few months, due both to low supply, especially at the entry level of the market, and very high prices. Single-family housing starts have also slipped, as homebuilders try to keep up with a heavy backlog of demand amid high prices for land, labor and materials. > There has been growing talk of a price bubble in the housing market, but the fundamentals of today’s market say otherwise. > “Although home price growth is reaching new highs, the risk of price declines has fallen far below pre-pandemic and summer 2006 levels, when homes prices last peaked. This is likely because favorable mortgage rates and income growth continue to keep the ratio of mortgage payments to monthly household income much lower today,” said Selma Hepp, deputy chief economist at CoreLogic. What are *the fundamentals*?
> “Consequently, elevated buyer demand, coupled with lacking for-sale inventories, will continue putting pressure on prices — which are likely to remain at double-digit increases through the third quarter of 2021,” she added. > Sales activity is gaining dramatically on the higher end of the market but falling on the low end as more buyers are priced out. Some blame the Federal Reserve for keeping mortgage rates artificially low, through its bond-buying program. Record low rates last year helped juice the homebuying boom, but those rates, now slightly higher, cannot offset the huge price gains.
Skewing higher a bit, latest number continuing a steep rise.
$255k for May and still rising $4-5k a month so on track for just over $270 based on current momentum. Think it will slow a little though, and the risk of a crash is not negligible
Updating slightly.  Recent comments by Shiller suggest that the price trend could continue for some time.

Based my initial estimate on the simple trend of previous year. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CSUSHPINSA  Also https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/29/home-price-gains-in-april-truly-extraordinary-sp-case-shiller-says.html
“Although home price growth is reaching new highs, the risk of price declines has fallen far below pre-pandemic and summer 2006 levels, when homes prices last peaked. This is likely because favorable mortgage rates and income growth continue to keep the ratio of mortgage payments to monthly household income much lower today,” said Selma Hepp, deputy chief economist at CoreLogic. “Consequently, elevated buyer demand, coupled with lacking for-sale inventories, will continue putting pressure on prices — which are likely to remain at double-digit increases through the third quarter of 2021,” she added. and Prof. Shiller himself also believes that the "housing frenzy" will continue for a year or so. And that the market sentiment is running the show, and there is not much that the Fed can do to stabilize without risk of creating a crash.

If growth continues at average pace since COVID, falls squarely into the 260-270.  See higher chance of cooling off rather than heating up more than current given recent pace of building permits, housing starts (adding supply).  Would have to be closer to pre COVID pace of growth to fall between 250-260, which looks less likely given increases in March/April.

Current rises in the index reflect pent up demand from 2020 and a realization amongst consumer forces that work from home options will be more viable here forward. However. The model of the central business district has not been completely destroyed and will continue to regain steam over the year. The recent sharp spike will also slow down towards the end of the summer has families will not move as much after the beginning of thr school year. It will still be a seller's market until most metros can correct their serious shortage of housing properties.

Some additional stats from the National Association of Realtors: https://www.nar.realtor/research-and-statistics/housing-statistics
From April to May:
*Prices up 2.5%
*Sales fell 0.9% 
*Days on the market was steady at 17.

New to this one.  Noted a number of well thought out rationales by my colleagues below (eg, Ryan-Beck, etc) about the growth rate.  Used Winter's Method to forecast out and this aligns with several forecaster comments below about the growth rate following the seasonal effect and moderating as we go into the fall.  Then aggregated with crowd 4cast, to make sure I'm not too far off base.

Case Schiller is running up about 14% yr/yr thru Apr. If that rate of growth holds, that would project a value of 261 for Oct 21. House buying season will come to a close by Oct, so that should reduce some demand-pull inflation, as such growth rates will hold or possibly soften a bit as we go into CQ4.
New $3.5T stimulus will prop up the market.

Historically it's tough to sustain +15% price growth.
My factors: direction of interest rates, employment rates, supply, sales price trough to peak %, sales volume strength.
As the winter cools down the US and the market with potential covid spikes, the FRED rate will regress towards the mean. Especially if/when the Fed announces a higher interest rate.

I think growth in home prices is likely to return to trend in the coming months. Home prices really jumped up, and I've heard much of the reason for that is that the supply of houses on the market cratered. Checking out some data on that [1] it looks like that's exactly right. Housing supply cratered in late spring/early summer 2020. That coincides with the beginning of the above-trend increase in housing prices according to the Case-Shiller metric [2]. As shown in [1], as of May the housing supply is back into the territory from before the pandemic. So I think it's likely that prices level off or return to trend soon. High prices incentivize home-owners to get their houses on the market and they also disincentivize buyers from buying at outrageous prices, and both these factors will put downward pressure on home prices.  It's also worth noting there's a seasonal effect to prices. As shown in [2], price growth peaks in the spring or early summer and drops back in the fall. Looking at the index history [3], since 2012 the change from April to October is 3% to 3.5%, with a minimum of 2.07% and a max of 5.8% in the history. If the same held this year that would result in the following: Average/Median: 256.5 to 257.8
Max: 263.5
Min: 254.2 Overall I think there's a higher chance of a return to trend or even a leveling off or dropping in price. But there is definitely a good chance I'm wrong and that the pandemic effects aren't over or that there are other effects encouraging price growth over the coming months. [1] FRED monthly housing supply: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/MSACSR [2] FRED Case-Shiller with units changed to % change: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=Fn1G [3] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1uVKRuSr1JJj5DA6ibzyIXjpEmVeL4pT74lrTXQycl78/edit?usp=sharing
$249,000 as at April, hard to see it rising another 10% by October. Hard to see it dropping though with current momentum

A slower rate of growth, at 2-3 pts/month, gets the index to 261-267. Growth a bit slower than that is also possible.
Lowering forecast for the 4th and 5th bins and raising the 2nd and 3rd.

* "The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller National Home Price Index measures the change in the value of the U.S. residential housing market by tracking the purchase price and resale value of single-family homes that have undergone a minimum of two arm's-length transactions." https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/sp_case_shiller_us_nhpi.asp
* Each S&P/Case-Shiller Index data point is actually a 3-month moving average. So, an April data point actually includes data from Feb. through April. https://www.economy.com/home/products/samples/case-shiller-FAQ.pdf
* Data for the S&P/Case-Shiller Index are currently available only through April 2021.
* The median home sales price fell a little in Q1 2021: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/MSPUS
* Because S&P/Case-Shiller Index data are 3-month moving average data, this index generally lags median home sales prices.  The S&P/Case-Shiller Index was going up through April, showing that the values of single-family homes, in general, were going up, but at the same time, in Q1 2021, buyers were actually buying slightly cheaper homes. If the median home sales price continues to fall below trend, it will likely pull this index down, too. The two metrics are not completely coupled, though; for instance, the median home sales price fell in Q2 2020, while the Case-Shiller Index continued to increase throughout and after that quarter. The median home sales price also tends to have slightly more volatility. Because the median home sales price fell in Q1, I'm going to bet on a slightly lower value of the S&P/Case-Shiller Index than if it continued to increase as steeply as it has since the pandemic started and especially in early 2021. I'll project an average of a 3-point raise over the next 6 months through October 2021, to 267, with wide error bars.

April 2021 is 249, and the price growth rate has accelerated for each of the past 4 months. It's been increasing 1-2% MoM for about 8 consecutive months and supply is still low. Pre-COVID MoM price growth rate was 0.4%. The conservative MoM growth rate of 0.4% gets us to 255 in October 2021. 1% MoM gets us to 264, and 2% MoM growth gets us to 280. None of the data available shows the recent effect of potential homebuyers balking at the skyrocketing prices though.
The index has moved 40 points in the last 6 months and us now at about 248. At this pace it would move 20 points by October, putting it at about 268.
